Generalized time evolution of the homogeneous cooling state of a granular gas with positive and negative coefficient of normal restitution

Nagi Khalil IFISC (CSIC-UIB), Instituto de FÃ­sica Interdisciplinar y Sistemas Complejos, Campus Universitat de les Illes Balears, E-07122, Palma de Mallorca, Spain. nagi@ifisc.uib-csic.es
Abstract

The homogeneous cooling state (HCS) of a granular gas described by the inelastic Boltzmann equation is reconsidered. As usual, particles are taken as inelastic hard disks or spheres, but now the coefficient of normal restitution Î±ğ›¼\alpha is allowed to take negative values Î±âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ›¼11\alpha\in[-1,1], a simple way of modeling more complicated inelastic interactions. The distribution function of the HCS is studied at the longâ€“time limit, as well as for intermediate times. At the longâ€“time limit, the relevant information of the HCS is given by a scaling distribution function Ï•sâ€‹(c)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ ğ‘\phi_{s}(c), where the time dependence occurs through a dimensionless velocity cğ‘c. For Î±â‰³âˆ’0.75greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ›¼0.75\alpha\gtrsim-0.75, Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s} remains close to the gaussian distribution in the thermal region, its cumulants and exponential tails being well described by the first Sonine approximation. On the contrary, for Î±â‰²âˆ’0.75less-than-or-similar-toğ›¼0.75\alpha\lesssim-0.75, the distribution function becomes multimodal, its maxima located at câ‰ 0ğ‘0c\neq 0, and its observable tails algebraic. The latter is a consequence of an unbalanced relaxationâ€“dissipation competition, and is analytically demonstrated for Î±â‰ƒâˆ’1similar-to-or-equalsğ›¼1\alpha\simeq-1 thanks to a reduction of the Boltzmann equation to a Fokkerâ€“Plankâ€“like equation. Finally, a generalized scaling solution to the Boltzmann equation is also found Ï•â€‹(c,Î²)italic-Ï•ğ‘ğ›½\phi(c,\beta). Apart from the time dependence occurring through the dimensionless velocity, Ï•â€‹(c,Î²)italic-Ï•ğ‘ğ›½\phi(c,\beta) depends on time through a new parameter Î²ğ›½\beta measuring the departure of the HCS from its longâ€“time limit. It is shown that Ï•â€‹(c,Î²)italic-Ï•ğ‘ğ›½\phi(c,\beta) describes the time evolution of the HCS for almost all times. The relevance of the new scaling is also discussed.

Keywords: granular matter, Kinetic Theory of gases and liquids

1 Introduction

The homogeneous cooling state (HCS) of a granular gas is one of the simplest states of an ensemble of grains that move freely between inelastic collisions. It describes a situation where the system remains spatially homogeneous and its granular temperature, proportional to its total kinetic energy, decreases monotonically in time. Moreover, if grains are modeled as smooth hard spheres with a constant and positive coefficient of normal restitution Î±ğ›¼\alpha, for the longâ€“time limit the HCS has two important properties. First, the granular temperature decays in time as âˆ¼1/t2similar-toabsent1superscriptğ‘¡2\sim 1/t^{2} according to Haffâ€™s law [1], and second, the distribution function depends on time only through its dependence on the granular temperature, its scaling form being close to the gaussian distribution in the thermal region and has exponential tails [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. In addition, the time dependence of the scaling distribution occurs only throught a dimensionless velocity. Similar features are found if grains have different mechanical properties [7, 8], are nonspherical [9, 10], or even if the model includes other details of the grains, such as roughness/rotations [11, 12, 13, 14], or velocity dependent collision coefficients [15, 16, 17].

The first objective of the present work is to complement the existence studies of the HCS by considering negative values of the coefficient of normal restitution (Î±<0ğ›¼0\alpha<0). The extension has two complementary motivations. On the one hand, some years ago numerical studies [18, 19] showed that two particles can collide with an effective negative Î±ğ›¼\alpha. A natural question then concerns the effect of Î±ğ›¼\alpha being negative on the global dynamics of the system. The actual value of the coefficient of restitution depends in general on the exact geometry of the collision, however as a first approximation we can take it as a constant and consider the collision rule for hard spheres with Î±âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ›¼11\alpha\in[-1,1], a model that can be theoretically studied by means of the kinetic Boltzmann equation and numerically solved with direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC). On the other hand, the new possibility opens up the door for a new phenomenology. Namely, one of the main features of granular matter is the indissolubly coupling between dissipation and dynamics: whenever there is a collision, and hence an eventual approach to equilibrium, there is a dissipation of energy, that is the system is also driven by itself out of equilibrium. In the case of hard spheres, when collisions become more and more elastic, Î±â†’1âˆ’â†’ğ›¼superscript1\alpha\to 1^{-}, the relaxation dominates the dissipation, in the sense that the scaling distribution function of the HCS becomes close to the maxwellian. The situation is completely different in the new elastic limit, Î±â†’âˆ’1+â†’ğ›¼superscript1\alpha\to-1^{+}, since now the equilibration mechanism of collisions as well as the dissipation become small (for Î±=âˆ’1ğ›¼1\alpha=-1 there is no collision at all, i.e. the ideal gas limit).

Despite its simplicity, the HCS is one of the most important states of a granular gas, since it plays the same role the equilibrium distribution plays for molecular gases. It turns out that a general hydrodynamics description for the grains can be derived, in the context of the Kinetic Theory, by using the longâ€“time limit of the distribution function of the HCS as a reference state [20, 21]. However, the aforementioned hydrodynamics has several limitations, with at least two different origins. First, the dynamics of the system has to be such that the longâ€“time limit of the HCS has to be reached by the system in a time scale much smaller than the hydrodynamic ones. This puts some limits to the values of the gradients and the dissipation. In fact, some authors argue that the usual hydrodynamics only applies in the elastic limit Î±â‰ƒ1similar-to-or-equalsğ›¼1\alpha\simeq 1 [21], while others claim that it also works for a wider range of dissipation [20]. Second, the usual hydrodynamics may also fail when describing some steady states of the grains where there is a direct coupling between gradients and dissipation, like in the uniform shear flow. In this cases, it is still possible to derive accurate closed hydrodynamic equations if, instead of the HCS, the appropriate reference state is identified [22, 23]. Interestingly, even though the simplest cases now correspond to homogeneous and steady situations (homogeneous and steady granular temperature), consistency requires that the new reference distribution function does depend on time. The very same situation is found when the system is globally driven by a thermostat [24, 25] and/or a plate [26].

Coming back to the freeâ€“cooling case, if one makes an appropriate change of the time variable [27], say Ï„âˆ¼lnâ¡tsimilar-toğœğ‘¡\tau\sim\ln t, the dynamics changes so that particles become accelerated while collisions are not affected. At the longâ€“time limit, the dissipation of energy due the inelastic collisions are compensated for by the acceleration, and the HCS becomes a steady state. The change of the time variable maps, in a reversible way, the original system into a granular gas in contact with an effective thermostat [27, 28, 29, 30]. Now we come across an apparent contradiction: the reference state of a gas in contact with a thermostat should be time dependent for consistency [31], but the longâ€“time limit of the HCS is a steady state in the new representation. The second objective of the present work is to unveil the contradiction by reconsidering the time evolution of the HCS in the steadyâ€“state representation.

The work is organized as follows. Next section presents the model, its kinetic description, and the steadyâ€“state representation of the HCS. Section 3 contains the theoretical and numerical results for the longâ€“time limit for Î±âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ›¼11\alpha\in[-1,1]. The limit Î±â†’âˆ’1â†’ğ›¼1\alpha\to-1 is studied with some details after a reduction of the inelastic Boltzmann equation to a Fokkerâ€“Plank type equation. The time evolution of the HCS is the content of Sec. 4. Finally, Sec. 5 is devoted to the conclusions.

2 Model, kinetic description, and steadyâ€“state representation

2.1 The model

The system is modeled as an ensemble of Nğ‘N hard spheres in dğ‘‘d dimensions, inside a square box of volume Ldsuperscriptğ¿ğ‘‘L^{d} with periodic boundary conditions. Particles have mass mğ‘šm, diameter Ïƒğœ\sigma, and move freely between collisions. If two particles with velocities ğ¯1subscriptğ¯1\mathbf{v}_{1} and ğ¯2subscriptğ¯2\mathbf{v}_{2} collide, their new velocities ğ¯1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ¯1â€²\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime} and ğ¯2â€²superscriptsubscriptğ¯2â€²\mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime} are

ğ¯2â€²=ğ¯2+1+Î±2â€‹[(ğ¯1âˆ’ğ¯2)â‹…ğˆ^]â€‹ğˆ^,superscriptsubscriptğ¯2â€²subscriptğ¯21ğ›¼2delimited-[]â‹…subscriptğ¯1subscriptğ¯2^ğˆ^ğˆ\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}=\mathbf{v}_{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2}[(\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{2})\cdot\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}]\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, (2)

with ğˆ^^ğˆ\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}} being a unit vector pointing from second to first particle at contact. The coefficient of normal restitution Î±ğ›¼\alpha is a number in [âˆ’1,1]11[-1,1] and characterizes the amount of energy Î”â€‹EÎ”ğ¸\Delta E dissipated in the collision as

Î”â€‹E=âˆ’m4â€‹(1âˆ’Î±2)â€‹[(ğ¯1âˆ’ğ¯2)â‹…ğˆ^]2.Î”ğ¸ğ‘š41superscriptğ›¼2superscriptdelimited-[]â‹…subscriptğ¯1subscriptğ¯2^ğˆ2\Delta E=-\frac{m}{4}(1-\alpha^{2})[(\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{2})\cdot\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}]^{2}. (3)

Observe that for the same precollisional velocities the energy dissipation is the same regardless the sign of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, while the postcollisional velocities are different in both cases. In fact, the two signs of Î±ğ›¼\alpha represent two different physical situations: while for Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0 we have collisions of smooth hard spheres, for Î±<0ğ›¼0\alpha<0 Eq. (3) is a simplification (i.e. gives the asymptotic velocities) of a more complicated interaction that may involve overlaps of particles and/or include a rotation of the contact plane of the two spheres [18, 19]. More clearly, for Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 particles collide elastically while for Î±=âˆ’1ğ›¼1\alpha=-1 there is no collision at all (ideal gas). One still can forget about the physical meaning of Î±<0ğ›¼0\alpha<0, and consider the collision rule as part of a new model of a granular gas that becomes close to the ideal gas at some limit, a limit that has it intrinsic interest.

2.3 Steadyâ€“state representation

Since collisions dissipate energy for Î±âˆˆ(âˆ’1,1)ğ›¼11\alpha\in(-1,1), the granular temperature is always a decreasing function of time. However, the change of the time variable introduced in [27] and further analyzed in [28] enables the system to reach a steady state. The new time scale does not change the dynamics of the system, but rather represents an useful way of observing it.

Let Î½0subscriptğœˆ0\nu_{0} and t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0} be arbitrary positive constants, with dimensions of frequency and time, respectively. We define a new time variable Ï„ğœ\tau as

Ï„=1Î½0â€‹lnâ¡tt0.ğœ1subscriptğœˆ0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0\displaystyle\tau=\frac{1}{\nu_{0}}\ln\frac{t}{t_{0}}. (12)

Then, if ğ«ğ«\mathbf{r} denotes the position of a particle, its velocity defined in terms of the new time is ğ°=ddâ€‹Ï„â€‹ğ«ğ°ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğœğ«\mathbf{w}=\frac{d}{d\tau}\mathbf{r} which gives

ğ°â€‹(Ï„)=Î½0â€‹tâ€‹ğ¯â€‹(t),ğ°ğœsubscriptğœˆ0ğ‘¡ğ¯ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}(\tau)=\nu_{0}t\mathbf{v}(t), (13)

that is, particles are accelerated between collisions. Moreover, since collisions are instantaneous, the same rules (1) and (6) apply for ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}, after replacing ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v} by ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}.

At the kinetic level, it is convenient to consider a new distribution function gâ€‹(ğ°,Ï„)ğ‘”ğ°ğœg(\mathbf{w},\tau) defined as

gâ€‹(ğ°,Ï„)=(Î½0â€‹t)âˆ’dâ€‹fâ€‹(ğ¯,t)ğ‘”ğ°ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœˆ0ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ¯ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w},\tau)=\left(\nu_{0}t\right)^{-d}f(\mathbf{v},t) (14)

which has the same normalization of fğ‘“f. Taking into account Eq. (4) for fğ‘“f, we get the following equation for gğ‘”g:

[âˆ‚âˆ‚Ï„+Î½0â€‹âˆ‚âˆ‚ğ°â‹…ğ°]â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°,Ï„)=Ïƒdâˆ’1â€‹Jâ€‹[ğ°|g],delimited-[]ğœâ‹…subscriptğœˆ0ğ°ğ°ğ‘”ğ°ğœsuperscriptğœğ‘‘1ğ½delimited-[]conditionalğ°ğ‘”\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial\tau}+\nu_{0}\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{w}}\cdot\mathbf{w}\right]g(\mathbf{w},\tau)=\sigma^{d-1}J[\mathbf{w}|g], (15)

where the collision operator Jğ½J is defined by Eq. (5). The fundamental difference of the present equation with respect to Eq. (4) is the presence of a new term in the l.h.s. As already mentions in Refs. [27, 28], the new term acts as a thermostat, injecting energy into the system, and allowing it to reach a steady state, as we analyze in the next section.

3 Longâ€“time limit

Equation (15) has a steadyâ€“state solution gsâ€‹(ğ°,Ï„)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ ğ°ğœg_{s}(\mathbf{w},\tau) describing the longâ€“time limit of the distribution function of the HCS. For Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0, the research on the distribution function has focused mainly on two aspects: their cumulants (providing information of the thermal region) and the tails, see for instance [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 28]. In this section, we extend the study to negative values of the coefficient of normal restitution.

3.2 Cumulants and tails

Equation (22) has an isotropic solution Ï•sâ€‹(c)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ ğ‘\phi_{s}(c) that can be expanded in terms of the Sonine polynomials [3] Snâ€‹(c2)subscriptğ‘†ğ‘›superscriptğ‘2S_{n}(c^{2}) as

In Fig. 1, the theoretical predictions of Eqs. (24) and (25) for a2,ssubscriptğ‘2ğ‘ a_{2,s} and Î¶sâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘ \zeta^{*}_{s} are compared against DSMC numerical results. For the first cumulant a2,ssubscriptğ‘2ğ‘ a_{2,s}, theory deviates from simulations moderately for |Î±|â‰²0.5less-than-or-similar-toğ›¼0.5|\alpha|\lesssim 0.5, and notably for Î±â‰²âˆ’1/2less-than-or-similar-toğ›¼12\alpha\lesssim-1/\sqrt{2}. 3.3 Loss of unimodality

An important conclusion is inferred from the theory and numerical results shown in Fig. 1. Namely, the distribution functions for the HCS at the steady state for Î±ğ›¼\alpha and âˆ’Î±ğ›¼-\alpha are different, specially if |Î±|â‰³1/2greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ›¼12|\alpha|\gtrsim 1/\sqrt{2} (the cumulants are quite different). The difference is dramatic for the two elastic limits: while for Î±â†’1â†’ğ›¼1\alpha\to 1 the distribution function tends to the gaussian distribution (all cumulants go to zero), for Î±â†’âˆ’1â†’ğ›¼1\alpha\to-1 the asymptotic distribution is different from the gaussian (the cumulants are different from zero). This scenario is fully supported by the left plot of Fig. 3 where the scaling distribution Ï•â€‹(c)italic-Ï•ğ‘\phi(c) is plotted for three values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, one close to 111 and two close to âˆ’11-1.

Figure 3 shows a qualitative change of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s} for câ‰²2less-than-or-similar-toğ‘2c\lesssim 2 (thermal region) as Î±ğ›¼\alpha decreases. Namely, there is a critical value Î±csubscriptğ›¼ğ‘\alpha_{c} of the coefficient of normal restitution behind which the distribution function becomes multimodal. More precisely, if cmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šc_{m} is the absolute value of ğœğœ\mathbf{c} where the maxima of Ï•sâ€‹(ğœ)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ ğœ\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}) occur, then the numerical simulations show that cmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šc_{m} changes continuously as cmâˆ¼Î±câˆ’Î±similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ğ›¼c_{m}\sim\sqrt{\alpha_{c}-\alpha} for Î±câ‰ƒâˆ’0.75similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ›¼ğ‘0.75\alpha_{c}\simeq-0.75, see the right plot of Fig. 3.

The loss of unimodality for Î±<Î±cğ›¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘\alpha<\alpha_{c} can be understand qualitatively as an unbalanced competition between the collisionâ€“inducing relaxation and the collisionâ€“inducing dissipation, as follows. Take Eq. (22) for ğœ=0ğœ0\mathbf{c}=0, and write it as

J+â€‹[0|Ï•s]âˆ’Jâˆ’â€‹[0|Ï•s]âˆ’d2â€‹Î¶sâˆ—â€‹Ï•sâ€‹(0)=0,superscriptğ½delimited-[]conditional0subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ superscriptğ½delimited-[]conditional0subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ ğ‘‘2subscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘ subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ 00J^{+}[0|\phi_{s}]-J^{-}[0|\phi_{s}]-\frac{d}{2}\zeta^{*}_{s}\phi_{s}(0)=0, (27)

where JÂ±superscriptğ½plus-or-minusJ^{\pm} are the contributions of the collision operator that accounts for the gain (++) and loose (âˆ’-) of particles with velocity ğœğœ\mathbf{c} around zero. For |Î±|â‰ƒ1similar-to-or-equalsğ›¼1|\alpha|\simeq 1 the term proportional to Î¶sâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘ \zeta^{*}_{s} can be dropped and the argumentation simplified. First, take as a reference Î±â‰ƒ1similar-to-or-equalsğ›¼1\alpha\simeq 1: the mean number of collisions that produces a particle with velocity around the origin J+superscriptğ½J^{+} coincides with the mean number of collisions that moves a particle from the origin to any other place Jâˆ’superscriptğ½J^{-}. For this case, J+superscriptğ½J^{+} involves particles with a wide range of velocities. Now take Î±â‰ƒâˆ’1similar-to-or-equalsğ›¼1\alpha\simeq-1, and assume that Jâˆ’superscriptğ½J^{-} does not change too much with respect to the previous case, since it depends essentially on the collision frequency. Since 1+Î±âˆ¼0similar-to1ğ›¼01+\alpha\sim 0 and the distribution function decays to zero very fast for câ‰³3greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘3c\gtrsim 3, the only way a particle around the origin to be created is that it was originally nearby. Hence, the wide range of pairs of velocities of case Î±â‰ƒ1similar-to-or-equalsğ›¼1\alpha\simeq 1 now reduces to a narrow region, that is the distribution function has to be bigger around the origin now.

Since we assumed câ‰ª1/|Ïµ|much-less-thanğ‘1italic-Ïµc\ll 1/|\epsilon| in the derivation of Eq. (33) (see just after Eq. (28)), Eq. Figure 4 compares the numerical simulations with Eq. (40) for the values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha for which the tails could be measured.

Two predictions of the present section, that of Eqs. (53)â€“(55), are compared against numerical simulations in Figs. 5 and 7. On the one hand, Eq. (53) is confirmed by Fig. 5 for a range of values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha for which the first Sonine approximation is expected to work, namely the range provided by the analysis of the steady state, see Fig. 1. For other values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, and if the initial cumulants are not small enough, the dependence of Î±2subscriptğ›¼2\alpha_{2} on Î²ğ›½\beta is also given by a law similar to Eq. (53), but with a different exponent Câ€‹(Î±)ğ¶ğ›¼C(\alpha), as Figs. 5 and 6 show. More precisely, Fig. 6 suggests the same origin of the failure of Eq. (53) as that of Eq. (24), that is, the contribution of cumulants of higher order. This is because we observe a data collapse, similar to that predicted by Eq. (53), only if all initial values have the same cumulants (left plot of Fig. 6) but this collapse is absent if the initial data have the same initial a2subscriptğ‘2a_{2} but different a3subscriptğ‘3a_{3} (right plot of Fig. 6). On the other hand, the theoretical prediction of Eq. (55) is fully confirmed by Fig. 6 for all values of the parameters and initial conditions, meaning that the contribution of the cumulants can be neglected even if the first Sonine approximation fails.

5 Discussion and conclusions

In this work we have proposed an extension of the existing studies on the homogeneous cooling state of a granular gas along two complementary directions. On the one hand, the usual hardâ€“sphere collision rule has been generalized by allowing the coefficient of normal restitution to take positive and negative values Î±âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ›¼11\alpha\in[-1,1]. This way, more complex collision processes have been modeled, as well as new situations of the granular gas, where the relative importance of dissipation and equilibration can be tuned, have been considered. Now, the elastic limit can be reached with Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (hard, elastic spheres) and also with Î±=âˆ’1ğ›¼1\alpha=-1 (ideal, collisionless gas). We have tried to realize to what extent the negative values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha modify the existing picture for Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0. On the other hand, we also reconsidered the time evolution of the HCS, motivated by recent advances on the research of driven granular gases. The study has been carried out by means of theoretical and numerical (DSMC) approaches, both based on the kinetic description provided by the inelastic Boltzmann equation.

At the longâ€“time limit, the relevant information about the dynamics of the HCS is encoded through the scaling distribution function Ï•sâ€‹(c)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ ğ‘\phi_{s}(c), defined in Eqs. (14) and (16). We have studied their first two cumulants and their tails for all values of Î±âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ›¼11\alpha\in[-1,1]. Three different regions of the space of Î±ğ›¼\alpha can be identified. For Î±â‰¥1/2ğ›¼12\alpha\geq 1/\sqrt{2}, we recovered the known properties of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s}, namely it stays close to the gaussian distribution in the thermal region, hence its cumulants are very small, and their tails are exponential. The region |Î±|â‰¤1/2ğ›¼12|\alpha|\leq 1/\sqrt{2} is characterized by an increase of the deviation of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s} from the gaussian distribution, while the values of the cumulants and exponential tails being almost independent of the sign of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. The latter means that, for this intermediate region, collisions have the same effect on the system, despite they are different. This is an example of two different collision rules, but conserving the number of particles and linear momentum, and being associated with the same energy dissipation, give rise to similar global behaviours of the system. Finally, for Î±<âˆ’1/2ğ›¼12\alpha<-1/\sqrt{2}, we observe an important change of the shape of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s} with respect to the other two regions: the cumulants take much bigger values and the distribution function becomes multimodal, meaning that its maxima now occur for velocities different from zero, provided Î±â‰²âˆ’0.75less-than-or-similar-toğ›¼0.75\alpha\lesssim-0.75. Within this region, the limit Î±âˆ¼âˆ’1similar-toğ›¼1\alpha\sim-1 has been studied in details. A simplification of the Boltzmann equation occurs, since collisions induce very small changes to the velocities. That is, not only is the energy dissipation very small (like for Î±âˆ¼1similar-toğ›¼1\alpha\sim 1) but also the randomization induced by collision is also very weak (in contrast to Î±âˆ¼1similar-toğ›¼1\alpha\sim 1). The new equation, which is of the Fokkerâ€“Plank type but with the diffusion and drift coefficients being functionals of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s}, provides a useful framework where the new phenomenology can be studied. Among many interesting results, we highlight that Ï•sâˆ¼0similar-tosubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ 0\phi_{s}\sim 0 for câˆ¼0similar-toğ‘0c\sim 0, the probability of finding a particle with velocity ğœğœ\mathbf{c} being accumulated around |ğœ|=cmğœsubscriptğ‘ğ‘š|\mathbf{c}|=c_{m} (âˆ¼1similar-toabsent1\sim 1 for the two dimensional case). Moreover, the exponential tails of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s} appear before new algebraic ones. To the best of our knowledge, such velocity (multimodal) distributions have never been observed so far.

The second part of the work has been intended to the time evolution of the HCS for a wider time window. We have shown that a consistent solution to the Boltzmann equation requires a scaling distribution function to depend on two dimensionless parameters Ï•â€‹(ğœ,Î²)italic-Ï•ğœğ›½\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta), the dimensionless velocity already present at the longâ€“time limit (cğ‘c) and a new one that measures the deviation of the HCS from its longâ€“time limit (Î²ğ›½\beta). We have provided explicit expressions for the first cumulant as a function of Î²ğ›½\beta, Eq. (53), as well as for the time dependence of the granular temperature, Eq. (55). The former turns out to be very accurate only if the cumulants are small enough, for any initial condition and for all relevant times (after a short transient of view collision per particle). The latter, on the contrary, is of general use. Despite the limitation of Eq. (53), the simulations shows that, in general, the second cumulant behaves in a similar way for any Î±âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ›¼11\alpha\in[-1,1], which in turn represents an important support of the existence of Ï•â€‹(ğœ,Î²)italic-Ï•ğœğ›½\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta).

The possibility of generalizing the results obtained for Ï•â€‹(ğœ,Î²)italic-Ï•ğœğ›½\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta), Eqs. (53) and (55), to any value of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, allowed us to discuss the actual importance of the new scaling solution in terms of the time the system takes to reach Ï•sâ€‹(ğœ)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ ğœ\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}). We have shown that for the relevant hydrodynamic time scales, the new scaling is only appreciable for Î±â‰¤âˆ’1/2ğ›¼12\alpha\leq-1/\sqrt{2}, provided the initial distribution is close enough to its long-time form. We find this as a very important result that gives support to the hydrodynamic description constructed from Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi_{s}. Nevertheless, we consider it necessary to consider Ï•â€‹(ğœ,Î²)italic-Ï•ğœğ›½\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta) if we were to wider the range of applicability of the aforementioned description.
